body:
I was just noticing a similar problem.
`New-Variable -Scope private -Name test -Value "D:\Users\brazg\Documents\test"`
if you type
`$global:test` or `$local:test` or `$private:test` they will all return the same value.
The scope can be anything at all it will still show on global, local and private.
`$env:test` is a seperate variable from the others.

Interesting, because if you write `Private` in lower-case (`private`), it will work as supposed. As I see, equality test made with case ignorance (https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/v6.1.0/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Utility/commands/utility/Var.cs#L832), but it doesn't work

@whitequill:

That's not a valid test, because if you use scope modifiers that in effect refer to the _same_ scope, variable access will still succeed; in the global scope, `$global:test`, `$local:test`, `$script:test` and `$private:test` all refer to the same `$test` variable in the global scope - whether the variable is private or not.

@yegorf1: The check is indeed case-insensitive, as it should be, and it does work - the case of scope modifier `private` is irrelevant.

Here's a statement that show that creating private variables with scope modifier `private` _does_ work (you can try it with any case variation of `private`) .

```powershell
# Be sure that you haven't previously created a $foo variable.
PS> $private:foo = 'private'; & { $global:foo }
# no output, because the child scope in { ... } doesn't see $foo in the global scope, 
# because it is private.
```

In short: Creating private variables with either of the following methods DOES currently work as intended:

 * `$private:varName = ...`
 * `New-Variable -Option Private varName ...`

By contrast, `New-Variable -Scope Private varName ...` does NOT - note the difference in parameter names: `-Option` vs. `-Scope`.

@mklement0 maybe you missed reading the documetation about scopes and how they are supposed to work.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_scopes?view=powershell-6
I may be mistaken on how `$local` works but `$private` should be its own scope independent of other variable names.

if `New-Variable -Scope` has to do with where the code is run and what code sees other code running, what does `New-Variable -Option` do if it is just setting a scope?

@whitequill: I've read the topic, but it doesn't tell you the whole story.

> if `New-Variable -Scope` has to do with where the code is run

`-Scope` specifies in what the scope the variable is _created_, as also reflected in the [`New-Variable`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.utility/new-variable?view=powershell-6) help topic:

> Specifies the scope of the new variable.

And that is indeed how it works for `-Scope Global`, `-Scope Script` and `-Scope Local`, but it doesn't work for `-Scope Private`, which is the inconsistency this issue is about.

An example of where it works:
 
```powershell
& { new-variable -scope script hi there } # from a child scope, create a variable in the script scope
$hi  # output the newly created script-scope variable
```

Note that in the global scope (from the command line) the  `script` scope is the same as the global scope.

> but `$private` should be its own scope independent of other variable names.

Strictly speaking, `private` is _not a separate scope_.
Instead, it is a _flag_ (option) on a _variable_ in a given scope that prevents descendant scopes from seeing its value or modifying it with explicit cross-scope access.

Thus, `New-Variable -Option Private` is the technically more accurate way to create a private variable - and it does work as intended.

You can even _combine_ that with `-Scope`  to create a private variable in a _different_ scope:

```powershell
& { new-variable -scope script -option Private hi there } # create private var. in script scope
$hi # OK, private script-level var. was created, and is (obviously) accessible in the script scope.
& { $hi } # NO output in child scope, because the script-scope variable is private.
```

Since variables in the  private "scope" are only ever accessible in the `local` i.e. current scope, there is some _technical_ justification in treating `-Scope Local` and `-Scope Private` both as `-Scope Local`, but it certainly _confounds user expectations_, needlessly so, not least because it works differently - and as expected - with `New-Alias`.
